maml:description.maml:para: Add a PSReminder to the database.

Add a PSReminder to the database. The command will use the global PSReminder variables, although you can override the server instance parameter. It is strongly recommended that you avoid using special characters, especially apostrophes and commas, in your event name or comment.
Enter the name of the event.
Enter the date and time for the event.
Specify an optional comment or description for the event.
Specify an optional array of tags.
The path to the SQLite database.
Show the event that was added to the database.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specify an optional comment or description for the event.
Enter the date and time for the event.
Enter the name of the event.
Specify an optional array of tags.
The path to the SQLite database.
Show the event that was added to the database.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Add a reminder to the database.

maml:description.maml:para: Export the PSReminder database.
SQLite doesn't have a backup mechanism like SQL Server. You can use this command to export the reminder database to a JSON file. You can use Import-PSReminderDatabase to restore it.
The path and filename for the export JSON file.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The path to the SQLite database
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The path to the SQLite database
The path and filename for the export JSON file.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Export the database to a JSON file.

maml:description.maml:para: Export PSReminder variables.

If you customize the PSReminder preference variables, such as the number of default days, instead of setting the value in your profile, you can export the variables to a JSON file stored in $HOME. When importing the module, the JSON file will be imported if found. Otherwise, the module will use the default values.
If you remove this module you will need to manually delete the .psreminder.json file from $HOME.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Write the preference file to the pipeline
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Write the preference file to the pipeline
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Get module information.
This is a simple command to provide summary information about the PSReminder module. This can be used for troubleshooting purposes.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-AboutPSReminder
ModuleName : PSReminderLite Version : 0.1.0 MySQLite : 0.13.0 SQLiteVersion : 3.42.0 PSVersion : 7.5.0-preview.3 Platform : Win32NT

maml:description.maml:para: Get one or more PSReminder entries.
This command will query the PSReminder database and return matching events. The parameters are used to fine-tune the query and should be self-explanatory.
Show all events in the EventData table. This will include expired events.
The path to the SQLite database
Show all events from the ArchivedEvent table.
The path to the SQLite database
The name of an event to search for.
The path to the SQLite database
Show expired events.
The path to the SQLite database
Select an event by its ID number.
The path to the SQLite database
Find events scheduled for the next number of days as defined by $PSReminderDefaultDays.
The path to the SQLite database
Select reminders by a tag. Wildcards are supported.
The path to the SQLite database
Show all events in the EventData table. This will include expired events.
Show all events from the ArchivedEvent table.
The name of an event to search for.
Show expired events.
Select an event by its ID number.
Find events scheduled for the next number of days as defined by $PSReminderDefaultDays.
Select reminders by a tag. Wildcards are supported.
The path to the SQLite database

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-PSReminder
ID Event Comment Date -- ----- ------- ---- 19 Migration Planning meeting prep docs 07/19/2024 02:28:… 23 Vendor phone call include Gladys 07/19/2024 13:30:… 1 Haircut 7/24/2024 8:30:00…

dev:remarks.maml:para: The default is to get reminders due in the next number of days defined in $PSReminderDefaultDays. The output will be color code. Events due within 24 hours will be red, and events due within 48 hours will be yellow.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-PSReminder -id 19 | select *
Name : Migration Planning meeting Event : Migration Planning meeting Date : 7/19/2024 2:28:06 AM Comment : prep docs ID : 19 Expired : False

dev:remarks.maml:para: The object has extended properties defined.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-PSReminder -All | Format-Table -view date
Month: Jul 2024
ID Event Comment Date -- ----- ------- ---- 19 Migration Planning meeti… prep docs 7/19/2024 2:28:06 AM 23 Vendor phone call include Gladys 7/19/2024 1:30:00 PM 1 Haircut 7/24/2024 8:30:00 AM ...

dev:remarks.maml:para: The module includes a custom formatting view.

maml:description.maml:para: Get information about the PSReminderEventDB database.
This command will display information about the PSReminder database.
The path to the SQLite database
The path to the SQLite database

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-PSReminderDBInformation
Database: C:\Users\Jeff\PSReminder.db [20KB]
Age Reminders Expired Archived --- --------- ------- -------- 00.01:47:55 25 3 2

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-PSReminderDBInformation | Select-Object *
Name : PSReminder.db Path : C:\Users\Jeff\PSReminder.db PageSize : 4096 PageCount : 5 Reminders : 25 Expired : 3 Archived : 2 Size : 20480 Created : 7/18/2024 9:31:22 AM Modified : 7/19/2024 11:09:39 AM Author : THINKX1-JH\Jeff Comment : PSReminderLite database Encoding : UTF-8 SQLiteVersion : 3.42.0 Age : 01:49:09.5592668 Date : 7/19/2024 12:58:48 PM Computername : THINKX1-JH

dev:remarks.maml:para: The information object has additional properties not seen in the default display.

maml:description.maml:para: Get defined PSReminder tags

This command makes it easier to view the $PSReminderTag variable. The output of the command will show the ANSI escape sequence formatted with the sequence. The output will show NULL styles for tags defined in the database but not in the variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-PSReminderTag
Tag Style --- ----- Personal `e[94m Event `e[33m Testing `e[3;92m Priority `e[1;3;38;5;199m Work `e[38;5;156m travel

dev:remarks.maml:para: The style will be formatted with the corresponding style.

maml:description.maml:para: Import PSReminder data from a JSON file.
If you export a PSReminder database with the Export-PSReminderDatabase command, you can re-import it into a new or different SQLite database file with this command.
The path and filename for the exported JSON file. It is assumed this file was created with Export-PSReminderDatabase.
The path to the SQLite database
Specify an optional comment for the database
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The path to the SQLite database
The path and filename for the exported JSON file. It is assumed this file was created with Export-PSReminderDatabase.
Specify an optional comment for the database
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Initialize a new PSReminder database.

Use this command to initialize a new PSReminder database and table. You need to specify the path for the new database file. The command will use the built-in PSReminder variables so update them if necessary before running this command.
Enter the full path for the SQLite database file. It should end in .db
Specify an optional comment for the database.
Write the database file object to the pipeline
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter the full path for the SQLite database file. It should end in .db
Specify an optional comment for the database.
Write the database file object to the pipeline
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Archive an expired PSReminder.
Expired events will remain in the primary table. Use this command to move expired events to the ArchivedEvent table. If you want to automate this process, add the command
Get-PSReminder -Expired | Archive-PSReminder
to your PowerShell profile. This command has an alias of Archive-PSReminder.
Specify an event ID to archive.
The path to the SQLite database
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specify an event ID to archive.
The path to the SQLite database
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Delete a PSReminder from the database.
Events in the PSReminder database remain, even though they may not be displayed by default. Normally, you can archive expired events. However, you can also delete entries with this command.
The ID number of the event you want to delete.
The path to the SQLite database
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The ID number of the event you want to delete.
The path to the SQLite database
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Delete an event from the database by ID number. This will NOT archive it but permanently delete it from the database.

maml:description.maml:para: Modify a PSReminder.
Use this command to update or modify an existing PSReminder. This command will use the PSReminder variables for its defaults.
The event ID. This is used to identify the event to update.
The new comment for the event.
The new date for the event.
The new name for the event.
Specify an optional array of tags
The path to the SQLite database.
Write the updated event to the pipeline.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The new comment for the event.
The new date for the event.
The new name for the event.
The event ID. This is used to identify the event to update.
Specify an optional array of tags
The path to the SQLite database.
Write the updated event to the pipeline.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Update the comment, date, and tags for the event with ID 11.
